column2: Concerning the means of procuring unity; men must beware, that in the procuring, or reuniting, of religious unity, they do not dissolve and deface the laws of charity, and of human society.
column3: Concerning the means of procuring unity; men must beware, that in the procuring, or reuniting, of religious unity, they do not dissolve and deface the laws of charity, and of human society.

column2: There be two swords amongst Christians, the spiritual and temporal; and both have their due office and place, in the maintenance of religion.
column3: There be two swords amongst Christians, the spiritual and temporal; and both have their due office and place, in the maintenance of religion.

column2: But we may not take up the third sword, which is Mahomet's sword, or like unto it; that is, to propagate religion by wars, or by sanguinary persecutions to force consciences; except it be in cases of overt scandal, blasphemy, or intermixture of practice against the state; much less to nourish seditions; to authorize conspiracies and rebellions; to put the sword into the people's hands; and the like; tending to the subversion of all government, which is the ordinance of God.
column3: But we may not take up the third sword, which is Mahomet's sword, or like unto it; that is, to propagate religion by wars, or by sanguinary persecutions to force consciences; except it be in cases of overt scandal, blasphemy, or intermixture of practice against the state; much less to nourish seditions; to authorize conspiracies and rebellions; to put the sword into the people's hands; and the like; tending to the subversion of all government, which is the ordinance of God.

column2: For this is but to dash the first table against the second; and so to consider men as Christians, as we forget that they are men.
column3: For this is but to dash the first table against the second; and so to consider men as Christians, as we forget that they are men.

column2: Lucretius the poet, when he beheld the act of Agamemnon, that could endure the sacrificing of his own daughter, exclaimed: Tantum Religio potuit suadere malorum.
column3: Lucretius the poet, when he beheld the act of Agamemnon, that could endure the sacrificing of his own daughter, exclaimed: Tantum Religio potuit suadere malorum.

column2: What would he have said, if he had known of the massacre in France, or the powder treason of England?
column3: What would he have said, if he had known of the massacre in France, or the powder treason of England?

column2: He would have been seven times more Epicure, and atheist, than he was.
column3: He would have been seven times more Epicure, and atheist, than he was.

column2: For as the temporal sword is to be drawn with great circumspection in cases of religion; so it is a thing monstrous to put it into the hands of the common people.
column3: For as the temporal sword is to be drawn with great circumspection in cases of religion; so it is a thing monstrous to put it into the hands of the common people.

column2: Let that be left unto the Anabaptists, and other furies.
column3: Let that be left unto the Anabaptists, and other furies.

column2: It was great blasphemy, when the devil said, I will ascend, and be like the highest; but it is greater blasphemy, to personate God, and bring him in saying, I will descend, and be like the prince of darkness; and what is it better, to make the cause of religion to descend, to the cruel and execrable actions of murthering princes, butchery of people, and subversion of states and governments?
column3: It was great blasphemy, when the devil said, I will ascend, and be like the highest; but it is greater blasphemy, to personate God, and bring him in saying, I will descend, and be like the prince of darkness; and what is it better, to make the cause of religion to descend, to the cruel and execrable actions of murthering princes, butchery of people, and subversion of states and governments?

column2: Surely this is to bring down the Holy Ghost, instead of the likeness of a dove, in the shape of a vulture or raven; and set, out of the bark of a Christian church, a flag of a bark of pirates, and assassins.
column3: Surely this is to bring down the Holy Ghost, instead of the likeness of a dove, in the shape of a vulture or raven; and set, out of the bark of a Christian church, a flag of a bark of pirates, and assassins.

column2: Therefore it is most necessary, that the church, by doctrine and decree, princes by their sword, and all learnings, both Christian and moral, as by their Mercury rod, do damn and send to hell for ever, those facts and opinions tending to the support of the same; as hath been already in good part done.
column3: Therefore it is most necessary, that the church, by doctrine and decree, princes by their sword, and all learnings, both Christian and moral, as by their Mercury rod, do damn and send to hell for ever, those facts and opinions tending to the support of the same; as hath been already in good part done.

column2: Surely in counsels concerning religion, that counsel of the apostle would be prefixed, Ira hominis non implet justitiam Dei.
column3: Surely in counsels concerning religion, that counsel of the apostle would be prefixed, Ira hominis non implet justitiam Dei.

column2: And it was a notable observation of a wise father, and no less ingenuously confessed; that those which held and persuaded pressure of consciences, were commonly interested therein, themselves, for their own ends.
column3: And it was a notable observation of a wise father, and no less ingenuously confessed; that those which held and persuaded pressure of consciences, were commonly interested therein, themselves, for their own ends.

column2: Of Revenge
column3: Of Revenge

column2: REVENGE is a kind of wild justice; which the more man's nature runs to, the more ought law to weed it out.
column3: REVENGE is a kind of wild justice; which the more man's nature runs to, the more ought law to weed it out.

column2: For as for the first wrong, it doth but offend the law; but the revenge of that wrong, putteth the law out of office.
column3: For as for the first wrong, it doth but offend the law; but the revenge of that wrong, putteth the law out of office.

column2: Certainly, in taking revenge, a man is but even with his enemy; but in passing it over, he is superior; for it is a prince's part to pardon.
column3: Certainly, in taking revenge, a man is but even with his enemy; but in passing it over, he is superior; for it is a prince's part to pardon.

column2: And Solomon, I am sure, saith, It is the glory of a man, to pass by an offence.
column3: And Solomon, I am sure, saith, It is the glory of a man, to pass by an offence.

column2: That which is past is gone, and irrevocable; and wise men have enough to do, with things present and to come; therefore they do but trifle with themselves, that labor in past matters.
column3: That which is past is gone, and irrevocable; and wise men have enough to do, with things present and to come; therefore they do but trifle with themselves, that labor in past matters.

column2: There is no man doth a wrong, for the wrong's sake; but thereby to purchase himself profit, or pleasure, or honor, or the like.
column3: There is no man doth a wrong, for the wrong's sake; but thereby to purchase himself profit, or pleasure, or honor, or the like.

column2: Therefore why should I be angry with a man, for loving himself better than me?
column3: Therefore why should I be angry with a man, for loving himself better than me?

column2: And if any man should do wrong, merely out of ill-nature, why, yet it is but like the thorn or briar, which prick and scratch, because they can do no other. The most tolerable sort of revenge, is for those wrongs which there is no law to remedy; but then let a man take heed, the revenge be such as there is no law to punish; else a man's enemy is still before hand, and it is two for one.
column3: And if any man should do wrong, merely out of ill nature, why, yet it is but like the thorn or briar, which prick and scratch, because they can do no other. The most tolerable sort of revenge, is for those wrongs which there is no law to remedy; but then let a man take heed, the revenge be such as there is no law to punish; else a man's enemy is still before hand, and it is two for one.

column2: Some, when they take revenge, are desirous, the party should know, whence it cometh.
column3: Some, when they take revenge, are desirous, the party should know, whence it cometh.

column2: This is the more generous.
column3: This is the more generous.

column2: For the delight seemeth to be, not so much in doing the hurt, as in making the party repent.
column3: For the delight seemeth to be, not so much in doing the hurt, as in making the party repent.

column2: But base and crafty cowards, are like the arrow that flieth in the dark.
column3: But base and crafty cowards, are like the arrow that flieth in the dark.

column2: Cosmus, duke of Florence, had a desperate saying against perfidious or neglecting friends, as if those wrongs were unpardonable; You shall read (saith he) that we are commanded to forgive our enemies; but you never read, that we are commanded to forgive our friends.
column3: Cosmus, duke of Florence, had a desperate saying against perfidious or neglecting friends, as if those wrongs were unpardonable; You shall read (saith he) that we are commanded to forgive our enemies; but you never read, that we are commanded to forgive our friends.

column2: But yet the spirit of Job was in a better tune: Shall we (saith he) take good at God's hands, and not be content to take evil also?
column3: But yet the spirit of Job was in a better tune: Shall we (saith he) take good at God's hands, and not be content to take evil also?

column2: And so of friends in a proportion.
column3: And so of friends in a proportion.

column2: This is certain, that a man that studieth revenge, keeps his own wounds green, which otherwise would heal, and do well.
column3: This is certain, that a man that studieth revenge, keeps his own wounds green, which otherwise would heal, and do well.

column2: Public revenges are for the most part fortunate; as that for the death of Caesar; for the death of Pertinax; for the death of Henry the Third of France; and many more.
column3: Public revenges are for the most part fortunate; as that for the death of Caesar; for the death of Pertinax; for the death of Henry the Third of France; and many more.

column2: But in private revenges, it is not so. Nay rather, vindictive persons live the life of witches; who, as they are mischievous, so end they infortunate.
column3: But in private revenges, it is not so. Nay rather, vindictive persons live the life of witches; who, as they are mischievous, so end they infortunate.

column2: Of Adversity
column3: Of Adversity

column2: IT WAS an high speech of Seneca (after the manner of the Stoics), that the good things, which belong to prosperity, are to be wished; but the good things, that belong to adversity, are to be admired.
column3: IT WAS an high speech of Seneca (after the manner of the Stoics), that the good things, which belong to prosperity, are to be wished; but the good things, that belong to adversity, are to be admired.

column2: Bona rerum secundarum optabilia; adversarum mirabilia.
column3: Bona rerum secundarum optabilia; adversarum mirabilia.

column2: Certainly if miracles be the command over nature, they appear most in adversity.
column3: Certainly if miracles be the command over nature, they appear most in adversity.

column2: It is yet a higher speech of his, than the other (much too high for a heathen), It is true greatness, to have in one the frailty of a man, and the security of a God.
column3: It is yet a higher speech of his, than the other (much too high for a heathen), It is true greatness, to have in one the frailty of a man, and the security of a God.

column2: Vere magnum habere fragilitatem hominis, securitatem Dei.
column3: Vere magnum habere fragilitatem hominis, securitatem Dei.

column2: This would have done better in poesy, where transcendences are more allowed. And the poets indeed have been busy with it; for it is in effect the thing, which figured in that strange fiction of the ancient poets, which seemeth not to be without mystery; nay, and to have some approach to the state of a Christian; that Hercules, when he went to unbind Prometheus (by whom human nature is represented), sailed the length of the great ocean, in an earthen pot or pitcher; lively describing Christian resolution, that saileth in the frail bark of the flesh, through the waves of the world.
column3: This would have done better in poesy, where transcendences are more allowed. And the poets indeed have been busy with it; for it is in effect the thing, which figured in that strange fiction of the ancient poets, which seemeth not to be without mystery; nay, and to have some approach to the state of a Christian; that Hercules, when he went to unbind Prometheus (by whom human nature is represented), sailed the length of the great ocean, in an earthen pot or pitcher; lively describing Christian resolution, that saileth in the frail bark of the flesh, through the waves of the world.

column2: But to speak in a mean.
column3: But to speak in a mean.

column2: The virtue of prosperity, is temperance; the virtue of adversity, is fortitude; which in morals is the more heroical virtue.
column3: The virtue of prosperity, is temperance; the virtue of adversity, is fortitude; which in morals is the more heroical virtue.

column2: Prosperity is the blessing of the Old Testament; adversity is the blessing of the New; which carrieth the greater benediction, and the clearer revelation of God's favor.
column3: Prosperity is the blessing of the Old Testament; adversity is the blessing of the New; which carrieth the greater benediction, and the clearer revelation of God's favor.

column2: Yet even in the Old Testament, if you listen to David's harp, you shall hear as many hearse-like airs as carols; and the pencil of the Holy Ghost hath labored more in describing the afflictions of Job, than the felicities of Solomon.
column3: Yet even in the Old Testament, if you listen to David's harp, you shall hear as many hearse like airs as carols; and the pencil of the Holy Ghost hath labored more in describing the afflictions of Job, than the felicities of Solomon.

column2: Prosperity is not without many fears and distastes; and adversity is not without comforts and hopes.
column3: Prosperity is not without many fears and distastes; and adversity is not without comforts and hopes.

column2: We see in needle-works and embroideries, it is more pleasing to have a lively work, upon a sad and solemn ground, than to have a dark and melancholy work, upon a lightsome ground: judge therefore of the pleasure of the heart, by the pleasure of the eye.
column3: We see in needle works and embroideries, it is more pleasing to have a lively work, upon a sad and solemn ground, than to have a dark and melancholy work, upon a lightsome ground: judge therefore of the pleasure of the heart, by the pleasure of the eye.

column2: Certainly virtue is like precious odors, most fragrant when they are incensed, or crushed: for prosperity doth best discover vice, but adversity doth best discover virtue.
column3: Certainly virtue is like precious odors, most fragrant when they are incensed, or crushed: for prosperity doth best discover vice, but adversity doth best discover virtue.

column2: Of Simulation And Dissimulation
column3: Of Simulation And Dissimulation

column2: DISSIMULATION is but a faint kind of policy, or wisdom; for it asketh a strong wit, and a strong heart, to know when to tell truth, and to do it.
column3: DISSIMULATION is but a faint kind of policy, or wisdom; for it asketh a strong wit, and a strong heart, to know when to tell truth, and to do it.

column2: Therefore it is the weaker sort of politics, that are the great dissemblers.
column3: Therefore it is the weaker sort of politics, that are the great dissemblers.

column2: Tacitus saith, Livia sorted well with the arts of her husband, and dissimulation of her son; attributing arts or policy to Augustus, and dissimulation to Tiberius.
column3: Tacitus saith, Livia sorted well with the arts of her husband, and dissimulation of her son; attributing arts or policy to Augustus, and dissimulation to Tiberius.

column2: And again, when Mucianus encourageth Vespasian, to take arms against Vitellius, he saith, We rise not against the piercing judgment of Augustus, nor the extreme caution or closeness of Tiberius.
column3: And again, when Mucianus encourageth Vespasian, to take arms against Vitellius, he saith, We rise not against the piercing judgment of Augustus, nor the extreme caution or closeness of Tiberius.

column2: These properties, of arts or policy, and dissimulation or closeness, are indeed habits and faculties several, and to be distinguished.
column3: These properties, of arts or policy, and dissimulation or closeness, are indeed habits and faculties several, and to be distinguished.

column2: For if a man have that penetration of judgment, as he can discern what things are to be laid open, and what to be secreted, and what to be showed at half lights, and to whom and when (which indeed are arts of state, and arts of life, as Tacitus well calleth them), to him, a habit of dissimulation is a hinderance and a poorness.
column3: For if a man have that penetration of judgment, as he can discern what things are to be laid open, and what to be secreted, and what to be showed at half lights, and to whom and when (which indeed are arts of state, and arts of life, as Tacitus well calleth them), to him, a habit of dissimulation is a hinderance and a poorness.

column2: But if a man cannot obtain to that judgment, then it is left to him generally, to be close, and a dissembler.
column3: But if a man cannot obtain to that judgment, then it is left to him generally, to be close, and a dissembler.

column2: For where a man cannot choose, or vary in particulars, there it is good to take the safest, and wariest way, in general; like the going softly, by one that cannot well see.
column3: For where a man cannot choose, or vary in particulars, there it is good to take the safest, and wariest way, in general; like the going softly, by one that cannot well see.

column2: Certainly the ablest men that ever were, have had all an openness, and frankness, of dealing; and a name of certainty and veracity; but then they were like horses well managed; for they could tell passing well, when to stop or turn; and at such times, when they thought the case indeed required dissimulation, if then they used it, it came to pass that the former opinion, spread abroad, of their good faith and clearness of dealing, made them almost invisible.
column3: Certainly the ablest men that ever were, have had all an openness, and frankness, of dealing; and a name of certainty and veracity; but then they were like horses well managed; for they could tell passing well, when to stop or turn; and at such times, when they thought the case indeed required dissimulation, if then they used it, it came to pass that the former opinion, spread abroad, of their good faith and clearness of dealing, made them almost invisible.

column2: There be three degrees of this hiding and veiling of a man's self.
column3: There be three degrees of this hiding and veiling of a man's self.

column2: The first, closeness, reservation, and secrecy; when a man leaveth himself without observation, or without hold to be taken, what he is.
column3: The first, closeness, reservation, and secrecy; when a man leaveth himself without observation, or without hold to be taken, what he is.

column2: The second, dissimulation, in the negative; when a man lets fall signs and arguments, that he is not, that he is.
column3: The second, dissimulation, in the negative; when a man lets fall signs and arguments, that he is not, that he is.

column2: And the third, simulation, in the affirmative; when a man industriously and expressly feigns and pretends to be, that he is not.
column3: And the third, simulation, in the affirmative; when a man industriously and expressly feigns and pretends to be, that he is not.

column2: For the first of these, secrecy; it is indeed the virtue of a confessor. And assuredly, the secret man heareth many confessions.
column3: For the first of these, secrecy; it is indeed the virtue of a confessor. And assuredly, the secret man heareth many confessions.

column2: For who will open himself, to a blab or a babbler?
column3: For who will open himself, to a blab or a babbler?

column2: But if a man be thought secret, it inviteth discovery; as the more close air sucketh in the more open; and as in confession, the revealing is not for worldly use, but for the ease of a man's heart, so secret men come to the knowledge of many things in that kind; while men rather discharge their minds, than impart their minds.
column3: But if a man be thought secret, it inviteth discovery; as the more close air sucketh in the more open; and as in confession, the revealing is not for worldly use, but for the ease of a man's heart, so secret men come to the knowledge of many things in that kind; while men rather discharge their minds, than impart their minds.

column2: In few words, mysteries are due to secrecy.
column3: In few words, mysteries are due to secrecy.

column2: Besides (to say truth) nakedness is uncomely, as well in mind as body; and it addeth no small reverence, to men's manners and actions, if they be not altogether open.
column3: Besides (to say truth) nakedness is uncomely, as well in mind as body; and it addeth no small reverence, to men's manners and actions, if they be not altogether open.

column2: As for talkers and futile persons, they are commonly vain and credulous withal.
column3: As for talkers and futile persons, they are commonly vain and credulous withal.

column2: For he that talketh what he knoweth, will also talk what he knoweth not.
column3: For he that talketh what he knoweth, will also talk what he knoweth not.

column2: Therefore set it down, that an habit of secrecy, is both politic and moral.
column3: Therefore set it down, that an habit of secrecy, is both politic and moral.

column2: And in this part, it is good that a man's face give his tongue leave to speak.
column3: And in this part, it is good that a man's face give his tongue leave to speak.

column2: For the discovery of a man' s self, by the tracts of his countenance, is a great weakness and betraying; by how much it is many times more marked, and believed, than a man's words.
column3: For the discovery of a man' s self, by the tracts of his countenance, is a great weakness and betraying; by how much it is many times more marked, and believed, than a man's words.

column2: For the second, which is dissimulation; it followeth many times upon secrecy, by a necessity; so that he that will be secret, must be a dissembler in some degree.
column3: For the second, which is dissimulation; it followeth many times upon secrecy, by a necessity; so that he that will be secret, must be a dissembler in some degree.

column2: For men are too cunning, to suffer a man to keep an indifferent carriage between both, and to be secret, without swaying the balance on either side.
column3: For men are too cunning, to suffer a man to keep an indifferent carriage between both, and to be secret, without swaying the balance on either side.

column2: They will so beset a man with questions, and draw him on, and pick it out of him, that, without an absurd silence, he must show an inclination one way; or if he do not, they will gather as much by his silence, as by his speech.
column3: They will so beset a man with questions, and draw him on, and pick it out of him, that, without an absurd silence, he must show an inclination one way; or if he do not, they will gather as much by his silence, as by his speech.

column2: As for equivocations, or oraculous speeches, they cannot hold out long.
column3: As for equivocations, or oraculous speeches, they cannot hold out long.

column2: So that no man can be secret, except he give himself a little scope of dissimulation; which is, as it were, but the skirts or train of secrecy.
column3: So that no man can be secret, except he give himself a little scope of dissimulation; which is, as it were, but the skirts or train of secrecy.

column2: But for the third degree, which is simulation, and false profession; that I hold more culpable, and less politic; except it be in great and rare matters.
column3: But for the third degree, which is simulation, and false profession; that I hold more culpable, and less politic; except it be in great and rare matters.

column2: And therefore a general custom of simulation (which is this last degree) is a vice, using either of a natural falseness or fearfulness, or of a mind that hath some main faults, which because a man must needs disguise, it maketh him practise simulation in other things, lest his hand should be out of use.
column3: And therefore a general custom of simulation (which is this last degree) is a vice, using either of a natural falseness or fearfulness, or of a mind that hath some main faults, which because a man must needs disguise, it maketh him practise simulation in other things, lest his hand should be out of use.

column2: The great advantages of simulation and dissimulation are three.
column3: The great advantages of simulation and dissimulation are three.

column2: First, to lay asleep opposition, and to surprise.
column3: First, to lay asleep opposition, and to surprise.

column2: For where a man's intentions are published, it is an alarum, to call up all that are against them. The second is, to reserve to a man's self a fair retreat.
column3: For where a man's intentions are published, it is an alarum, to call up all that are against them. The second is, to reserve to a man's self a fair retreat.

column2: For if a man engage himself by a manifest declaration, he must go through or take a fall.
column3: For if a man engage himself by a manifest declaration, he must go through or take a fall.

column2: The third is, the better to discover the mind of another.
column3: The third is, the better to discover the mind of another.

column2: For to him that opens himself, men will hardly show themselves adverse; but will fair let him go on, and turn their freedom of speech, to freedom of thought.
column3: For to him that opens himself, men will hardly show themselves adverse; but will fair let him go on, and turn their freedom of speech, to freedom of thought.

column2: And therefore it is a good shrewd proverb of the Spaniard, Tell a lie and find a troth.
column3: And therefore it is a good shrewd proverb of the Spaniard, Tell a lie and find a troth.

column2: As if there were no way of discovery, but by simulation.
column3: As if there were no way of discovery, but by simulation.

column2: There be also three disadvantages, to set it even.
column3: There be also three disadvantages, to set it even.

column2: The first, that simulation and dissimulation commonly carry with them a show of fearfulness, which in any business, doth spoil the feathers, of round flying up to the mark.
column3: The first, that simulation and dissimulation commonly carry with them a show of fearfulness, which in any business, doth spoil the feathers, of round flying up to the mark.

column2: The second, that it puzzleth and perplexeth the conceits of many, that perhaps would otherwise co-operate with him; and makes a man walk almost alone, to his own ends.
column3: The second, that it puzzleth and perplexeth the conceits of many, that perhaps would otherwise co-operate with him; and makes a man walk almost alone, to his own ends.

column2: The third and greatest is, that it depriveth a man of one of the most principal instruments for action; which is trust and belief.
column3: The third and greatest is, that it depriveth a man of one of the most principal instruments for action; which is trust and belief.

column2: The best composition and temperature, is to have openness in fame and opinion; secrecy in habit; dissimulation in seasonable use; and a power to feign, if there be no remedy.
column3: The best composition and temperature, is to have openness in fame and opinion; secrecy in habit; dissimulation in seasonable use; and a power to feign, if there be no remedy.

column2: Of Parents And Children
column3: Of Parents And Children

column2: THE joys of parents are secret; and so are their griefs and fears. They cannot utter the one; nor they will not utter the other.
column3: THE joys of parents are secret; and so are their griefs and fears. They cannot utter the one; nor they will not utter the other.

column2: Children sweeten labors; but they make misfortunes more bitter.
column3: Children sweeten labors; but they make misfortunes more bitter.

column2: They increase the cares of life; but they mitigate the remembrance of death.
column3: They increase the cares of life; but they mitigate the remembrance of death.

column2: The perpetuity by generation is common to beasts; but memory, merit, and noble works, are proper to men.
column3: The perpetuity by generation is common to beasts; but memory, merit, and noble works, are proper to men.

column2: And surely a man shall see the noblest works and foundations have proceeded from childless men; which have sought to express the images of their minds, where those of their bodies have failed.
column3: And surely a man shall see the noblest works and foundations have proceeded from childless men; which have sought to express the images of their minds, where those of their bodies have failed.

column2: So the care of posterity is most in them, that have no posterity.
column3: So the care of posterity is most in them, that have no posterity.

column2: They that are the first raisers of their houses, are most indulgent towards their children; beholding them as the continuance, not only of their kind, but of their work; and so both children and creatures.
column3: They that are the first raisers of their houses, are most indulgent towards their children; beholding them as the continuance, not only of their kind, but of their work; and so both children and creatures.

column2: The difference in affection, of parents towards their several children, is many times unequal; and sometimes unworthy; especially in the mothers; as Solomon saith, A wise son rejoiceth the father, but an ungracious son shames the mother.
column3: The difference in affection, of parents towards their several children, is many times unequal; and sometimes unworthy; especially in the mothers; as Solomon saith, A wise son rejoiceth the father, but an ungracious son shames the mother.

column2: A man shall see, where there is a house full of children, one or two of the eldest respected, and the youngest made wantons; but in the midst, some that are as it were forgotten, who many times, nevertheless, prove the best.
column3: A man shall see, where there is a house full of children, one or two of the eldest respected, and the youngest made wantons; but in the midst, some that are as it were forgotten, who many times, nevertheless, prove the best.

column2: The illiberality of parents, in allowance towards their children, is an harmful error; makes them base; acquaints them with shifts; makes them sort with mean company; and makes them surfeit more when they come to plenty.
column3: The illiberality of parents, in allowance towards their children, is an harmful error; makes them base; acquaints them with shifts; makes them sort with mean company; and makes them surfeit more when they come to plenty.

column2: And therefore the proof is best, when men keep their authority towards the children, but not their purse.
column3: And therefore the proof is best, when men keep their authority towards the children, but not their purse.

column2: Men have a foolish manner (both parents and schoolmasters and servants) in creating and breeding an emulation between brothers, during childhood, which many times sorteth to discord when they are men, and disturbeth families.
column3: Men have a foolish manner (both parents and schoolmasters and servants) in creating and breeding an emulation between brothers, during childhood, which many times sorteth to discord when they are men, and disturbeth families.

column2: The Italians make little difference between children, and nephews or near kinsfolks; but so they be of the lump, they care not though they pass not through their own body.
column3: The Italians make little difference between children, and nephews or near kinsfolks; but so they be of the lump, they care not though they pass not through their own body.

column2: And, to say truth, in nature it is much a like matter; insomuch that we see a nephew sometimes resembleth an uncle, or a kinsman, more than his own parent; as the blood happens. Let parents choose betimes, the vocations and courses they mean their children should take; for then they are most flexible; and let them not too much apply themselves to the disposition of their children, as thinking they will take best to that, which they have most mind to. It is true, that if the affection or aptness of the children be extraordinary, then it is good not to cross it; but generally the precept is good, optimum elige, suave et facile illud faciet consuetudo. Younger brothers are commonly fortunate, but seldom or never where the elder are disinherited.
column3: And, to say truth, in nature it is much a like matter; insomuch that we see a nephew sometimes resembleth an uncle, or a kinsman, more than his own parent; as the blood happens. Let parents choose betimes, the vocations and courses they mean their children should take; for then they are most flexible; and let them not too much apply themselves to the disposition of their children, as thinking they will take best to that, which they have most mind to. It is true, that if the affection or aptness of the children be extraordinary, then it is good not to cross it; but generally the precept is good, optimum elige, suave et facile illud faciet consuetudo. Younger brothers are commonly fortunate, but seldom or never where the elder are disinherited.

column2: Of Marriage And Single Life
column3: Of Marriage And Single Life

column2: HE THAT hath wife and children hath given hostages to fortune; for they are impediments to great enterprises, either of virtue or mischief. Certainly the best works, and of greatest merit for the public, have proceeded from the unmarried or childless men; which both in affection and means, have married and endowed the public.
column3: HE THAT hath wife and children hath given hostages to fortune; for they are impediments to great enterprises, either of virtue or mischief. Certainly the best works, and of greatest merit for the public, have proceeded from the unmarried or childless men; which both in affection and means, have married and endowed the public.

column2: Yet it were great reason that those that have children, should have greatest care of future times; unto which they know they must transmit their dearest pledges. Some there are, who though they lead a single life, yet their thoughts do end with themselves, and account future times impertinences.
column3: Yet it were great reason that those that have children, should have greatest care of future times; unto which they know they must transmit their dearest pledges. Some there are, who though they lead a single life, yet their thoughts do end with themselves, and account future times impertinences.

column2: Nay, there are some other, that account wife and children, but as bills of charges.
column3: Nay, there are some other, that account wife and children, but as bills of charges.

column2: Nay more, there are some foolish rich covetous men, that take a pride, in having no children, because they may be thought so much the richer.
column3: Nay more, there are some foolish rich covetous men, that take a pride, in having no children, because they may be thought so much the richer.

column2: For perhaps they have heard some talk, Such an one is a great rich man, and another except to it, Yea, but he hath a great charge of children; as if it were an abatement to his riches.
column3: For perhaps they have heard some talk, Such an one is a great rich man, and another except to it, Yea, but he hath a great charge of children; as if it were an abatement to his riches.

column2: But the most ordinary cause of a single life, is liberty, especially in certain self-pleasing and humorous minds, which are so sensible of every restraint, as they will go near to think their girdles and garters, to be bonds and shackles.
column3: But the most ordinary cause of a single life, is liberty, especially in certain self pleasing and humorous minds, which are so sensible of every restraint, as they will go near to think their girdles and garters, to be bonds and shackles.

column2: Unmarried men are best friends, best masters, best servants; but not always best subjects; for they are light to run away; and almost all fugitives, are of that condition.
column3: Unmarried men are best friends, best masters, best servants; but not always best subjects; for they are light to run away; and almost all fugitives, are of that condition.

column2: A single life doth well with churchmen; for charity will hardly water the ground, where it must first fill a pool.
column3: A single life doth well with churchmen; for charity will hardly water the ground, where it must first fill a pool.

column2: It is indifferent for judges and magistrates; for if they be facile and corrupt, you shall have a servant, five times worse than a wife.
column3: It is indifferent for judges and magistrates; for if they be facile and corrupt, you shall have a servant, five times worse than a wife.

column2: For soldiers, I find the generals commonly in their hortatives, put men in mind of their wives and children; and I think the despising of marriage amongst the Turks, maketh the vulgar soldier more base.
column3: For soldiers, I find the generals commonly in their hortatives, put men in mind of their wives and children; and I think the despising of marriage amongst the Turks, maketh the vulgar soldier more base.

column2: Certainly wife and children are a kind of discipline of humanity; and single men, though they may be many times more charitable, because their means are less exhaust, yet, on the other side, they are more cruel and hardhearted (good to make severe inquisitors), because their tenderness is not so oft called upon.
column3: Certainly wife and children are a kind of discipline of humanity; and single men, though they may be many times more charitable, because their means are less exhaust, yet, on the other side, they are more cruel and hardhearted (good to make severe inquisitors), because their tenderness is not so oft called upon.

column2: Grave natures, led by custom, and therefore constant, are commonly loving husbands, as was said of Ulysses, vetulam suam praetulit immortalitati. Chaste women are often proud and froward, as presuming upon the merit of their chastity.
column3: Grave natures, led by custom, and therefore constant, are commonly loving husbands, as was said of Ulysses, vetulam suam praetulit immortalitati. Chaste women are often proud and froward, as presuming upon the merit of their chastity.

column2: It is one of the best bonds, both of chastity and obedience, in the wife, if she think her husband wise; which she will never do, if she find him jealous.
column3: It is one of the best bonds, both of chastity and obedience, in the wife, if she think her husband wise; which she will never do, if she find him jealous.

column2: Wives are young men's mistresses; companions for middle age; and old men's nurses.
column3: Wives are young men's mistresses; companions for middle age; and old men's nurses.

column2: So as a man may have a quarrel to marry, when he will.
column3: So as a man may have a quarrel to marry, when he will.

column2: But yet he was reputed one of the wise men, that made answer to the question, when a man should marry,--A young man not yet, an elder man not at all.
column3: But yet he was reputed one of the wise men, that made answer to the question, when a man should marry,--A young man not yet, an elder man not at all.

column2: It is often seen that bad husbands, have very good wives; whether it be, that it raiseth the price of their husband's kindness, when it comes; or that the wives take a pride in their patience.
column3: It is often seen that bad husbands, have very good wives; whether it be, that it raiseth the price of their husband's kindness, when it comes; or that the wives take a pride in their patience.

column2: But this never fails, if the bad husbands were of their own choosing, against their friends' consent; for then they will be sure to make good their own folly.
column3: But this never fails, if the bad husbands were of their own choosing, against their friends' consent; for then they will be sure to make good their own folly.
